content: For anyone who's interested in properly arming themselves while they still can: As some of you will recall, a couple months ago I started a thread mentioning that I was picking up a GP WASR 10/63 semi-auto AK clone while I still could, before B.O.'s impending trampling of our 2nd Amendment rights with a new, more restrictive, no-sunset "AW"B. That rifle was built from old mil-spec Romanian parts, (matching set), on a new Romanian receiver. It had nice hardwood handguards, (as opposed to laminate), and it was built well overall. So she worked well, but she wasn't very pretty. I found an interested local buyer and sold it for $800 cash face-to-face. Yeah, I did well on that deal. Anyway.. I did some more research of the currently available semi-auto AK's and their manufacturers etc and I determined that the best way to go was to buy one newly manufactured by actual Russians at their Izhmash arms factory. Some here will recognize that as the factory that exports "sporting" Saiga "self-loading hunting carbines" to the US. The way they're generally imported is as a neutered "hunting" semi-auto AK, with a monte carlo stock, the trigger group moved rearward to accommodate that, without the ability to accept "high capacity" magazines, and no barrel threading or bayonet lug. Many people buy them that way and then "convert" em themselves, to use a proper pistol grip and use proper 30 round mags. They're excellent quality rifles, but I didn't want to buy a project, I wanted to buy a complete weapon. So.. I found that Arsenal Inc. working together with Legion, (the custom rifle shop at Izhmash), have started offering a "de-sporterized", proper mil-spec rifle, that's still new Russian production. It's basically a semi-auto AK103, (minus the cool, unique folding stock). They call it the Arsenal SGL20. I finally picked mine up on Monday.. and it is one amazing rifle. It is built as perfectly as the AK design allows, with all the military features, (besides selective fire), such as pistol grip, (of course), dimples in the receiver above the magazine well, barrel threaded for the AK74 muzzle brake, and forward positioned bayonet lug to allow bayonets to be attached with that larger brake. Her action is smooth as buttah and she is the most accurate AK I've ever fired, (<1" groups at 50 yrds). They're currently going for ~$950 online. I advise anyone who is looking for a very high quality stamped receiver AK to look into Arsenal's products.. both the Russian SGL20 and the excellent Bulgarian AK models they offer. All are new production rifles, which really sets them apart in the AK market. A company called Lancaster also offers AK rifles that look good for around that price, but their parts are inferior, (Romanian "G" parts kits), the build of the rifles is sometimes terrible, (like the one I bought and returned unfired), and their customer service is atrocious. Avoid their products. Here are a few pics: This message has been edited. Last edited by: shades_of_grey, Wed 01 April 2009 09:38 PM

content: For anyone who's interested in properly arming themselves while they still can: As some of you will recall, a couple months ago I started a thread mentioning that I was picking up a GP WASR 10/63 semi-auto AK clone while I still could, before B.O.'s impending trampling of our 2nd Amendment rights with a new, more restrictive, no-sunset "AW"B. That rifle was built from old mil-spec Romanian parts, (matching set), on a new Romanian receiver. It had nice hardwood handguards, (as opposed to laminate), and it was built well overall. So she worked well, but she wasn't very pretty. I found an interested local buyer and sold it for $800 cash face-to-face. Yeah, I did well on that deal. Anyway.. I did some more research of the currently available semi-auto AK's and their manufacturers etc and I determined that the best way to go was to buy one newly manufactured by actual Russians at their Izhmash arms factory. Some here will recognize that as the factory that exports "sporting" Saiga "self-loading hunting carbines" to the US. The way they're generally imported is as a neutered "hunting" semi-auto AK, with a monte carlo stock, the trigger group moved rearward to accommodate that, without the ability to accept "high capacity" magazines, and no barrel threading or bayonet lug. Many people buy them that way and then "convert" em themselves, to use a proper pistol grip and use proper 30 round mags. They're excellent quality rifles, but I didn't want to buy a project, I wanted to buy a complete weapon. So.. I found that Arsenal Inc. working together with Legion, (the custom rifle shop at Izhmash), have started offering a "de-sporterized", proper mil-spec rifle, that's still new Russian production. It's basically a semi-auto AK103, (minus the cool, unique folding stock). They call it the Arsenal SGL20. I finally picked mine up on Monday.. and it is one amazing rifle. It is built as perfectly as the AK design allows, with all the military features, (besides selective fire), such as pistol grip, (of course), dimples in the receiver above the magazine well, barrel threaded for the AK74 muzzle brake, and forward positioned bayonet lug to allow bayonets to be attached with that larger brake. Her action is smooth as buttah and she is the most accurate AK I've ever fired, (<1" groups at 50 yrds). They're currently going for ~$950 online. I advise anyone who is looking for a very high quality stamped receiver AK to look into Arsenal's products.. both the Russian SGL20 and the excellent Bulgarian AK models they offer. All are new production rifles, which really sets them apart in the AK market. A company called Lancaster also offers AK rifles that look good for around that price, but their parts are inferior, (Romanian "G" parts kits), the build of the rifles is sometimes terrible, (like the one I bought and returned unfired), and their customer service is atrocious. content: For anyone who's interested in properly arming themselves while they still can: As some of you will recall, a couple months ago I started a thread mentioning that I was picking up a GP WASR 10/63 semi-auto AK clone while I still could, before B.O.'s impending trampling of our 2nd Amendment rights with a new, more restrictive, no-sunset "AW"B. That rifle was built from old mil-spec Romanian parts, (matching set), on a new Romanian receiver. It had nice hardwood handguards, (as opposed to laminate), and it was built well overall. So she worked well, but she wasn't very pretty. I found an interested local buyer and sold it for $800 cash face-to-face. Yeah, I did well on that deal. Anyway.. I did some more research of the currently available semi-auto AK's and their manufacturers etc and I determined that the best way to go was to buy one newly manufactured by actual Russians at their Izhmash arms factory. Some here will recognize that as the factory that exports "sporting" Saiga "self-loading hunting carbines" to the US. The way they're generally imported is as a neutered "hunting" semi-auto AK, with a monte carlo stock, the trigger group moved rearward to accommodate that, without the ability to accept "high capacity" magazines, and no barrel threading or bayonet lug. Many people buy them that way and then "convert" em themselves, to use a proper pistol grip and use proper 30 round mags. They're excellent quality rifles, but I didn't want to buy a project, I wanted to buy a complete weapon. So.. I found that Arsenal Inc. working together with Legion, (the custom rifle shop at Izhmash), have started offering a "de-sporterized", proper mil-spec rifle, that's still new Russian production. It's basically a semi-auto AK103, (minus the cool, unique folding stock). They call it the Arsenal SGL20. I finally picked mine up on Monday.. and it is one amazing rifle. It is built as perfectly as the AK design allows, with all the military features, (besides selective fire), such as pistol grip, (of course), dimples in the receiver above the magazine well, barrel threaded for the AK74 muzzle brake, and forward positioned bayonet lug to allow bayonets to be attached with that larger brake. Her action is smooth as buttah and she is the most accurate AK I've ever fired, (<1" groups at 50 yrds). They're currently going for ~$950 online. I advise anyone who is looking for a very high quality stamped receiver AK to look into Arsenal's products.. both the Russian SGL20 and the excellent Bulgarian AK models they offer. All are new production rifles, which really sets them apart in the AK market. A company called Lancaster also offers AK rifles that look good for around that price, but their parts are inferior, (Romanian "G" parts kits), the build of the rifles is sometimes terrible, (like the one I bought and returned unfired), and their customer service is atrocious.
